Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back rather well-modelled with single lines marking clypeus, prothorax and elytra; humeral callosities shown as winglets; at side, legs well understood, represented by broad incised lines forming a triangle, but not cut away; underside bearing incised hieroglyphic inscription arranged horizontally; longitudinally pierced; glaze lost; core creamy yellow.
Curator's comments: This scarab is a product from the Scarab Factory where it was discovered (see F for Scarab Factory in Petrie 1886; pl. XXXVII, no. 103; on its various productions, see Gorton 1996, 91-131; Webb forthcoming). The cross-shaped sign and small circles, which are associated with the name of Amun, are typical of Naukratis scarabs (see especially Gorton 1996, Type XXVIII C, 105-106). However, the scarab does not fit perfectly Gorton's type XXVIII by its rather large size and the technique used (incision rather than stamp). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 103)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.120) (phase 3)
